awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: L.E.A.R.N.ing To Build STEM Research Communities- A Proposal to Strengthen, Expand, and Disseminate a Successful Retention Model
awd_abstract_narration:
A previous NSF-supported project has resulted in high retention and improved GPA for STEM majors at the University of Central Florida.  In an effort to expand on this work the institution has partnered with investigators at the University of NC-Wilmington (a primarily undergraduate, public institution) and Florida Atlantic University (a research-1, public institution) to study the ways in which a community built on disciplinary research will affect the retention of first-year students in STEM.  The participants will live together in a learning community, take courses together, and work as research apprentices in faculty laboratories.  This model, which has been shown to be particularly effective with students from underrepresented groups and first generation majors, will be adapted to include strategies for retaining transfer students through to graduation as well.

The core elements of the UCF model are the development of an academic research community that provides students with hands-on learning opportunities, access to faculty and trained graduate student and peer research mentors, and integration into student life through a wide variety of academic, social, and service activities.  This project will address three research questions that are central to the national goal of increasing the number of high quality STEM graduates who go on to graduate school and into the workforce: (a) Can the UCF research community model be adapted successfully to accommodate a transfer student population? (b) What factors within a STEM research community influence transfer student success and impact transfer student retention? And (c) To what extent is the retention success of a current model replicable at other, public institutions?  Formative and summative assessment will focus on the efficacy of the model on student retention and success in STEM for the different student populations (first-year and transfer) and at different institutions.  The plan will use a mixed-method approach to assess the effectiveness of the proposed educational tools and educational content in fulfilling the desired learning outcomes, from both educators' and participants' perspectives.  Student retention and GPA will be compared to matched cohorts.  The findings from this project will be presented at state and national meetings such as the Florida Statewide Symposium on Engagement in Undergraduate Research and the Council on Undergraduate Research biennial conference.  Results will also be submitted to the Journal of College Science Teaching.

por.por_cntn:
Faculty at Florida Atlantic University (FAU) partnered with investigators at Western Carolina University (WCU), (primarily undergraduate, public institution) and University of Central Florida (UCF), (research-1, public institution) to study the ways in which a community built on disciplinary research will affect student success of first year STEM, FTIC and community-college transfer students. The three institutions, FAU, WCU, and UCF comprised the LEARN® Consortium. Two programs were established/adapted and implemented at all three institutions from 2016-2022: F-LEARN for first-year students and T-LEARN for community college transfers. While F-and T-LEARN students differ in time and path to degree, both groups were attending a comprehensive 4-year university for the first time and would experience transition challenges. The F-LEARN model, originally established at UCF has been shown to be effective with students from underrepresented groups and first-generation majors. (Schneider et al 2012) Results from the first L.E.A.R.N. cohorts show improved retention, graduation rates, and critical thinking skills. This model was adapted and implemented at the other two institutions in the LEARN® Consortium. At FAU, F-LEARN students did not live together in a residential living, learning community and were only paired with faculty.  Collectively the LEARN® Consortium also adapted the successful Freshman model to a transfer student population to create T-LEARN. Within the new transfer student model, we included strategies for retaining transfer students through to graduation, and addressed barriers to retention of STEM transfer students, while retaining the three core components of the original model (Academics and Research, Mentoring, and Community).

Both F- and T-LEARN students participate in a learning community, take courses together, and work with faculty on research in faculty laboratories, consistent with the three core components. This project addressed three research questions:

  1. To what extent is the retention success of a current FTIC STEM research community program replicable at two different institutions?
  2. What factors within a STEM research community influence transfer student success and impact transfer student retention?
  3. How adaptable is UCF’s successful FTIC STEM research community program to an AA/AS transfer student population at three institutions with different student populations?

We implemented the following goals: (a) Adapt the current L.E.A.R.N. model to a transfer student population (T-L.E.A.R.N.) at UCF, FAU, and WCU, (b) Implement the L.E.A.R.N. model for FTIC students (F-L.E.A.R.N.) to WCU and FAU, (c) Assess the impacts of the L.E.A.R.N. consortium on student retention and success in STEM for different student populations and at different institutions, and (d) Disseminate the L.E.A.R.N. model to expand the L.E.A.R.N. consortium (Meeroff et al. 2020). Formative and summative assessment focused on the efficacy of the model on STEM student retention, GPA and success at different institutions compared to matched cohorts. Our overall findings from the three institutions indicate that T-LEARN students’ involvement in research during their 1st year was the most significant factor that contributed to their academic success. Additionally, most of these students continued to do research with the same LEARN program faculty mentor 1 year (and sometimes longer) after the program ended. (Chamely-Wiik et al. 2021) We continue to see increased graduation rates, and improved Fall-Fall retention in STEM for both cohorts. By Fall 2020, 68.4% of our T-LEARN Cohort 1 (16-17) had graduated in STEM compared to graduation rates of only 41.3% of the students in the matched comparison group.

The project findings were presented at 17 state and national meetings such as the Florida Statewide Symposium on Engagement in Undergraduate Research, the Council on Undergraduate Research biennial conference, and the American Society of Engineering Educators conference, and the authors have published three manuscripts.

  1. Chamely-Wiik D, E Frazier, D Meeroff, J Merritt, WR Kwochka, AI Morrison-Shetlar, M Aldarondo-Jeffries, J Johnson, KR Schneider. (2021). Undergraduate Research Communities for Transfer Students: Factors that Most Influence Student Success. Journal of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning. 21 (1): 193-224
  2. Meeroff, D., Chamely-Wiik, D., Kwochka, W. R., Frazier, E. M., Merritt, J., Aldarondo-Jeffries, M., Morrison-Shetlar, A. I., & Schneider, K. R. (2019) “Work in Progress: A Transferable Model to Improve Retention and Student Success in STEM through Undergraduate Research (NSF LEARN Consortium)” Paper presented at 2019 ASEE Annual Conference & Exposition, Tampa, Florida. https://peer.asee.org/33587
  3. Schneider K, U Nair, R Straney, P Lancey, and M Tripp. "First-Year STEM Research Program Facilitates Long-Term Academic Success" Journal of College Science Teaching, v.50 (4) ,2021, p.11

The consortium continues to explore the impact of the LEARN program with three additional peer-reviewed articles in preparation; 1. how has F-LEARN adaptation impacted students on the WCU and FAU campuses (Kwochka et al. In Prep), 2. the impact of LEARN on STEM transfer students’ retention, graduation, and critical thinking (Schneider et. Al In Prep, and 3. evaluation of the impact of the LEARN courses on students’ research learning outcomes (Chamely-Wiik et al. In Prep). The LEARN program at FAU has also now been sustained.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2022
Modified by: Donna M Chamely-Wiik

To what      extent is the retention success of a current FTIC STEM research community      program replicable at two different institutions?
What factors      within a STEM research community influence transfer student success and      impact transfer student retention?
How adaptable      is UCF’s successful FTIC STEM research community program to an AA/AS      transfer student population at three institutions with different student      populations?


We implemented the following goals: (a) Adapt the current L.E.A.R.N. model to a transfer student population (T-L.E.A.R.N.) at UCF, FAU, and WCU, (b) Implement the L.E.A.R.N. model for FTIC students (F-L.E.A.R.N.) to WCU and FAU, (c) Assess the impacts of the L.E.A.R.N. consortium on student retention and success in STEM for different student populations and at different institutions, and (d) Disseminate the L.E.A.R.N. model to expand the L.E.A.R.N. consortium (Meeroff et al. 2020).
